ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Close reading skills
writing skills
writing skills using archives
archive research
world wide knowledge
This course developed my ability to discuss books that explore post-colonial narratives with precise and sensitive language.
Better ability to Close Read and analyze the forms of texts especially alongside archival texts.
I learned how to interact with Yale's virtual archives to write a paper that is supported by primary sources. I also worked more on my close reading skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: all strengths. A fantastic course and Prof. Richards made it a wonderful way to start the morning and a truly supportive and bonding classmate experience.

Strengths: amazing class culture; this was made possible by a small seminar size but also the warmth, understanding, and flexibility of the professor 
Weaknesses: some of the chosen readings, while fascinating, were too long such that that seminar couldn't delve in deep enough

There are no weaknesses to this course! The intimate size of the class provided for free-flowing and engaging conversations and allowed the class to develop a close bond as we discussed books that cover some difficult subject matters.

The syllabus of this course is outstanding. All of the texts we read, specifically in the final unit, were interesting and provided a wide variety of perspectives from each region we studied. Prof. Richards also did an excellent job adapting to online instruction. A point of improvement could be more supplementary assignments so that the grade in the course isn't solely determined by the papers.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Weekly check-ins were a life saver and helped establish a connection that a very difficult to foster in a zoom seminar.
The virtual seminar format worked well, as did Professor Richards' use of videos to supplement lectures in class.

I think that this course, of all that  I took this semester, adapted best to online learning. Prof. Richards understood that we were all in different circumstances and locations, and we checked in with each other at the beginning of every week to see how we were all doing. We also watched several videos and used breakout rooms well to explore online archives and websites relevant to the texts we studied.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would. I would say at times the reading gets a little heavy but overall it is a great chance to read works from outside the US that otherwise you might never have come across. All in all, extremely informative and I certainly gained a lot.

Yes! This class is essential to anyone who wishes to work in the humanities. It has helped shaped my understanding of the power of words to communicate what may not be easily seen and the legacies that imperialism have left behind in formerly colonized nations.
Yes, it was a great class to find important and interesting literature outside of the Western sphere. I also really enjoyed discussion with my peers and professor.
Definitely. Reading non-Western works is so important to have a broader understanding of literature, and this course provides an excellent overview.
